summary: Website for the Bey Hub X tournament/community that lets users create teams of 1–3 with a team icon upload, request to join teams with leader approval, and includes an in-app inbox (“mail”) plus team footage video uploads.
architectural_notes: User selected option B: implement a built-in in-app inbox (“mail”) within the website; do not rely on external email sending.
Add a business rule: each authenticated user (Principal) may belong to at most one team at a time; block create-team and join-request actions if already on a team.
Temporarily avoid using the custom domain as primary until DNS is correctly configured; keep the default deployment URL as the working canonical entrypoint.
known_issues: The UI labeled “upload PDFs” is currently being used/understood as the team icon upload area; PDF attachment workflow may be incorrect or out of scope.
beyhubx.com currently returns "server IP address cannot be found" (DNS/custom-domain not resolving); site should be reverted to default URL until DNS is fixed.

existing_features.title: Implement Internet Identity authentication so users can sign in and the app can associate actions (team creation, join requests, approvals) with the signed-in Principal.

Support attaching PDFs to a team by allowing users to upload (or paste/import) PDF files on the frontend and store them in the backend associated with the team (including filename and binary content), with explicit per-file size limits and clear error handling when limits are exceeded.

Implement join-request workflow: users can request to join an existing team; the team leader can approve or deny requests; only approved users become team members, and approvals must not exceed the 3-member team limit.
Build the core UI screens for tournament team management: landing/home, create team, browse/list teams, team detail (members + PDFs), and leader dashboard for join-request approvals.

Apply a coherent, tournament-themed visual design across the app (colors, typography, spacing, component styling) using Tailwind/Shadcn, with a distinct “arena” feel suitable for Beyblade X (avoid default/unstyled screens).
Generate and include static visual assets for the app theme (logo/wordmark and a hero/background graphic) and render them in the UI from frontend/public/assets/generated.
Replace the current PDF uploader UI on the Create Team page with a Team Icon uploader that accepts common image formats (PNG/JPG/WebP) and clearly labels the field as a team icon (not PDFs).
Update the Team Detail page to remove the "Tournament PDFs" section (PDF list + PDF uploader) and instead display the team icon (if present) and allow the team leader to upload/replace the team icon.
Update frontend React Query hooks and types to use the new team icon API instead of the existing `uploadFile`/PDF flow for the icon uploader.
Rename all user-facing app/site text from "Beyblade X Tournament" / "Beyblade X Teams" to "Bey Hub X" across the UI (header branding, home hero title, footer, and any page titles/descriptions).
Implement an in-app mail/inbox system (no real email) that allows authenticated users to receive and view messages inside the website.

Update the team join flow so that requesting to join a team requires leader consent via the in-app mail system: when a user requests to join, a join-request mail item must be delivered to the team leader, and the leader must be able to approve or deny from the mail system.
Add the ability for a team leader to disband/delete their team from the UI, with backend enforcement that only the team leader can perform the action.

Replace/repurpose the remaining "Upload PDFs" messaging/sections in the UI to instead present "Upload Team Footage" and implement team footage video uploads (members-only) with browsing/playback on the team page.
Update the Create Team UI to block team creation when the signed-in user is already on a team, and guide the user to their current team instead.
Update team joining UI to prevent sending join requests when the signed-in user is already on a different team, including clear messaging.
Configure the deployed site to use the custom domain "beyhubx.com" as the primary website URL.
Update the frontend HTML head metadata to reflect the canonical site URL "https://beyhubx.com" (e.g., canonical link and/or Open Graph URL) so shared links and previews resolve to the new domain.
Remove the hard-coded redirect-to-domain behavior so the app no longer forces navigation to https://beyhubx.com and remains reachable on the platform’s default/working URL.

Update frontend HTML head metadata to stop hard-coding https://beyhubx.com as the canonical/preview URL (canonical link, og:url, twitter:url) so metadata does not point to an unreachable domain while DNS is not configured.

new_feature_requests.summary: Allow users to request to join an existing team, requiring consent/approval from the team leader/creator.

Create backend data models and API methods to support Beyblade X teams with a maximum size of 3, including: create team (with initial members), list teams, get team details, and enforce membership limits.
Replace/repurpose the current “upload PDFs” UI to support uploading a team icon (image) for the team instead of PDFs.
Add backend support for storing a single team icon per team (image bytes + filename and/or content type) and expose methods to upload/replace and to fetch it as part of team data needed by the UI.
Rename the app/site from “Beyblade X tournament” to “Bey Hub X” across UI and branding.
Add an in-app “mail”/inbox system (internal to the website; no real email) to deliver notifications/requests between users (e.g., join requests to leaders).
Add the ability for a team leader to disband/delete their team.
Change team join flow so a user must send a join request that is delivered via the in-app mail system and requires leader consent/approval.
Replace the middle “upload PDFs” section with “Upload Team Footage” allowing teams to upload videos (training, battles, reveals, etc.), including storage and browsing/viewing in the UI.
Enforce single-team membership per user: once a user creates or joins a team, they cannot create another team or request/join a different team unless they leave/disband their current team.

Enforce single-team membership on the backend: if a user is already a member of any existing team, prevent them from creating a new team, requesting to join another team, or being approved into another team.
Add a backend query API that allows the frontend to determine whether the authenticated caller is currently on a team, and if so, which team.
Revert the deployed site configuration from the custom domain (beyhubx.com) back to the previous default/working URL so the site is reachable again.
